comments.commentBody: So this means that sometime in 2012, the manufacturers of Windoze machines will ship a product with hardware comparable to that of the MacBook Air, available since October 2008.  Big whoop!  I saw many of these prototypes at CES, but no one in any of the booths showing them could tell me if they had been validated with Ubuntu.
It seems that no one does any R&D or take any risks. Just copy what Apple does.

Its incredible, isn't it? Starting with the Apple II, you now have the Mac (GUI), iPod, iTunes, iPhone, App Store, iPad, Mac OSX and iOS, and MacBook Air all being outright copied by the PC industry. Additionally, Apple was one of the original investors in ARM which powers most of the post PC devices.

All the Windows, Intel and Android apologists really have no leg to stand on. Without Apple's innovations, their products would be vastly different, and might not even exist.

“Let’s not give too much credit to the folks at Cupertino,” said Mike Hockey, an H.P. spokesman. “We’ve always had those thin and light PCs.”

And how well did you do?

how about a thin, lite ultrabook/tablet designed to let me look at 2 pages at once - like a book or magazine -
Please - 2 screens and a keyboard, in a light, portable package. That would get me interested. (I could always turn of one screen to save power)

My husband owns an HP windows laptop that is newer than my MacBook Pro. His has crashed several times since he purchased it a few years ago. My MacBook always works and is so much easier to use.
How could anyone consider it intuitive to go to the "Start" icon when you want to shut down the computer?

Why not buy the genuine article instead of a Windows machine that the manufacturers will abandon six months after their introduction.  I bought a MacBook Pro two months ago, and I doubt I'll ever buy another Windows laptop for personal use. This computer has been completely trouble-free.  I had it up and running on my home network within 5 minutes of the unboxing.  The battery life is head and shoulders above the battery life of my previous Windows laptops.  Flash is no longer an issue, because flash plug-ins are available for both Safari and Firefox.

This little computer that they are talking about is one in which they hope to sell. Heulet Packard has always done a pretty good job with their things. I owned a printer which printed really nice pictures. I have them to my family and friends and everyone loved them. The only problem with the ulterthin Notebook is on the regular PCs it is hard to find what is needed, where on the Mac's it is really easy. I have iPhoto, iTunes the mail or my e-mail address  the Internet which is a compass  where everything can be foundWord Microsoft Exell Word as well as Powerpoint all put out by Microsoft. This is a job well done by Apple and they also help teach everyone how to use their things. I had a big Compac as well as an Apple PC which was orange and I must say it was easier to find the stuff on the Apple. I now own a MacBook Pro and everything is right in front of me. Apple puts everything right there so it is easy to find. I had a Dell which was just awful. The C decided to stick and it did so for the longest time. I have friends who have had problems with them as well. For the people who write this article, good job.

Not true. That PC can have its MS Windows operating system swapped-out for any one of several dozen major Linux distributions, at no cost.

See http://distrowatch.com/dwres.php?resource=major for lots of information about the Top Ten Linux Distributions.
Ultrabook, ultrashnook, thePCs are still stuck with MS Windows. Apple wins.
The boot time of an Asus Zenbook is 15 seconds from a cold start and 2 seconds resume from sleep. Can the Macbook Air do better?
A Ferrari is not just its exterior design. The difference between the MacBook Air & the Ultrabooks is the clunky Microsoft engine. What's the boot time of each device?

Apple is actually often not the creator of a product. For example, windows mobile phones featured a modern OS (vs. relatively simple OS in Palm and Blackberry) long before Apple put iOS into iPhone. What's amazing is Apple's ability to create the product at the right time, in the right form, and at the right price. After Apple gets it done, all competitors realize "Oh, it should've been done in this way!"

It's time the myth regarding the impact of the iPad and tablets on the sales slowdown in PCs/notebooks be put to rest. Last quarter, Apple's iPad sales were themselves soft and what saved Apple was the iPhone, which really does not compete at all with PC's. The real serious factors contributing to slower PC/notebook sales as noted in the article have been the weak world economy, which slows both corporate and consumer sales, but also it must be recognized, the maturity of the PC/notebook category and the immense existing installed base. It is easy to show huge percentage sales gains for a new category coming into existence with a zero or small base.

I and one of my computer savvy friends evaluated the ergonomics and functionality of the iPad and other tablets early last year, and I more recently have lived with an iPad2 and have gotten first hand experience with its strengths and limitations, which only reinforced the initial impression. Early on we felt the iPad and this new class would be good for what Steve Jobs originally intended it to be, a convenient, cool, mobile device for accessing media and communicating limited messages/content/media to others. What we categorically rejected was its functionality as a device for any kind of serious work.

While tablets will continue as special segment of the computer market, the new generation of UltraBooks and light/thin Macs are likely, very likely to pick up the torch for the future of non-desktop or mobile computing.

I'm still waiting for this -- a full size (8.5"x11") touch-screen tablet that attaches to a keyboard to become a full, powerful laptop. Also, can someone plz make a tablet with thumb scroll buttons on each side? So I can browse web, click links, move page, etc., without touching the screen? (that's SO much work) And surround the right thumb scroll with up, down, left, right arrows and the left with back, enter, tab and control.
the ultralights were amazing at CES.  i would love to see AMD do a ultralight for less than $600. all my pc's are amd, and they work great.....

I always wonder why these articles don't mention the Toshiba Portege, it's always seemed one of the best in this category to me. Under 2.5 pounds, with 13" screen and built in DVD drive, you can get it with a 512 gig solid state drive and 8 gigs of main memory and a fast i7-2640M processor, 1" thick pretty impressive machine. A version without the built in DVD is only 0.63" thick. To me, easily the best of the ultra light machines (including the Air).

Not true, C. Kent. The PCs from Lenovo we have break often within 6 - 12 months, while the Macs last 5-6 years without repairs or upgrades. I've been doing this for nearly 20 years in large organizations so I know. Apple is unbeatable on performance and price. Start thinking in terms of total cost of ownership over 5 years and a lightbulb will come on for you too. And I write this on my Lenovo T410.

Thinness is a useless spec, and of course the thin Apple laptops break and/or flake out at a much higher rate than more substantial products. One more promo for obscure Apple toys built for people with more money than sense.

I think they're quite doomed. The MBA is a real luxury item with a unique OS. None of the ultrabooks have that, and even with Intel's money, they aren't hitting low price points, they're still trying to compete on specs. Which doesn't work. The high end Windows laptop market is functionally dead, and this will be a last gasp. When AMD offers a cheaper platform it can succeed. It's been the same with ipad competitors - none of them moved at higher than ipad prices. Because none of them have Apple's brand, and Apple has a true luxury brand.

None of these PC guys are using branding properly. Look at how automakers and clothes retailers do it. Alienware and Voodoo should have been their luxury brands, but they didn't nurture them, they keep inventing sub-brands like HP's envy and Adamo. That isn't a real luxury strategy.

Finally, the PC makers need to acknowledge the strength of Apple's Stores. They're like dealerships, they're essential to a luxury brand and they're not matched by Microsoft's stores, because MS stores don't have the same discounts or mission or knowledge. These guys need to wake up and realize how Apple's success is built on the right building blocks and that their methods are obsolete. Windows 8 won't change the fundamentals for them.

As an owner of MacBook Airs since the model debuted, my experiences have been largely positive. The designs have improved with each release. Mistakes, such as weak hinges in the original MacBook Air, have been fixed. The best aspects of the latest model are the self-contained operating system installation, the App Store, SSD and 4 GB RAM standard. Thunderbird is promising, but requires more compatible peripherals.

I have both an iPad and a MacBook Air, and use both often. But, for many consumers, I suspect the MacBook Air alone is more than sufficient. Once you've equipped an iPad with a protective case and perhaps a hard keyboard, it weighs as much as the small MacBook Air.

The question is whether the ultrabooks will represent a meaningful challenge to Apple's dominance of the ultraportable market. (It sells 90% of computers that cost $999 or more in the U.S.) Past efforts were unable to do so, with, perhaps the Dell Adamo coming closest in design and usability. Unfortunately, until the Adamo went on clearance it always cost more than the MacBook Air.

A computer is more than hardware. Saying the capabilities of Lion and iOS are equal is unrealistic. Some people would like to have an incredibly mobile system with the power of Lion or Windows (not just flash and more peripherals).

As a computer user who hates viruses, slow running machines and constant crashes, I've been a Mac fan my whole life. However, I really thought the MacBook Air would've been defunct by now, since it's basically just an iPad with a keyboard (okay, it supports Flash and more peripherals, I know, but still ...)

It's already there: Linux. And it's free.

See http://distrowatch.com/dwres.php?resource=major for lots of information on the Top Ten Linux Distributions.
Now if they could just get a better operating system.
Love my  Macbook air. (we now have two) Tried a Ipad, very nice but returned it. The form factor just didn't work as well as a laptop. Even my two teenage kids agree.
"Sidelong glance"? Have you taken a look at the lightweight laptops at Best Buy? More like "staring fixedly". In their case, imitation is the most clueless form of flattery.
Windows 8 is likely to help quite a lot in this respect.  One PC maker at the show told me that its hardware developers are getting a three-second cold-boot time.

"Manufacturers are finding plenty of ways to distinguish their Ultrabooks from one another," and yet they all run Windows. Perhaps that has something to do with why Apple's customers have been willing to pay a premium for MacBook Airs?

The Dell XPS 13 was mentioned in Chen's article, toward the top.  It was introduced late in the show, but was one of the cooler models: very thin, cast aluminum, gorilla glass, mag alloy, and carbon fiber materials.

Bring them on!.  As one who is toying with the idea of buying an IPad2 (which to me is still a toy), what I want is a tablet sized (and light) device that has the functionality of the iPad2 but also has the functionality of present day laptops - the ability to produce word processing documents in Word and to receive and send them as attachments.  In 2008 I spent $2,700 for a 3-pound Lenovo (running on Windows XP) to replace the 5-pound   MacBook I was lugging around when I traveled.  It made a difference. I hope in the near future I can buy an Ultrabook with a cool Solid State drive, more capacity than my present laptop, which would function like an iPad plus a working laptop with a weight of half of my present Lenovo or less (ideally with the weight of the iPad2).
What will a 3 or 4-yr old Ultrabook be worth?  I think I'll stick with the Macs.

Quote:

'Instead of waiting for 30 minutes on the phone and struggling to make myself be understood by a tech from India'

- So you don't talk to immigrants and others who are difficult to understand??

I completely agree. I order from Amazon not primarily because of price, but because I can choose a product based on other buyers reviewed and I know if the its is not right Amazon will return or replace it with no questions asked. I can order an item and have it the next day here in Manhattan.

In today's retail world, it's likely I am going to have to self-service whether or not I shop locally or over the internet anyway - I can't count the number of times I have gone to a local store and asked a question about the product and find I know more about it already than the "sales consultant" does. Or call to check if something is in stock and then travel to the store only to be told they think they are out. No thanks.

I do believe that tax laws should be fair and while I hate paying sales tax, think internet retailers should have to if local stores do.

If local businesses want to survive, they can't compete on price, but they can compete on service and knowledge - a rarity in any store today, low-end like Walmart or higher end like Saks.

I like Etsy and Amazon, too. Amazon does have excellent customer service - for both buyers and sellers. They are starting to compete with PayPal for the market on other websites, too. Could that be the reason for some of this amazon backlash?

I think people can support smaller sellers by buying at amazon. It is hard for the seller to compete with some of the prices there, but they are there for the consumer to purchase from, and can easily be recognized, in part, by their more 'realistic' prices. And people get the same Amazon protections.

Another website I like is bonanza. If you are a shopper who longs for the small time sellers that used to be at Ebay, but are no longer there, look to bonanza. There are lots of mom and pop operations in that neck of the woods. And amazon is a payment option. Plus they have some refreshingly creative marketing strategies happening.

I'm an avid Etsy fan, and I love buying local produce and delight in finding local businesses, especially independent toy stores and book shops. But I say little online retailers often located out of state from their main customers complaining about Amazon--um, really?

Amazon's customer service is excellent. I've gotten an order stolen from my front door. Instead of waiting for 30 minutes on the phone and struggling to make myself be understood by a tech from India, I filled out a quick form and a delightful Amazon customer representative speaking perfect American English called me back instantly at my convenience, clucked sympathetically at my dilemma, and sent a new order express mail! I didn't have to fill out any crazy forms, take photos of my empty box, etc. I was amazed they had total trust that as a customer I would not try to cheat them. The fact that they take customer feedback and experience seriously (no stupid voice software, less extraneous packaging, and encouraging a huge reviewer community), makes me a loyal and happy customer.

Bah. Then last week, I went to three Barnes and Nobles looking for the Hugo Cabret book. Not one of them stocked it. It's not by any means an obscure book thanks to Martin Scorsese. Only 1 in 3 of the service reps I found offered to even order it for me. B&N also had a 40 percent markup over Amazon. You really think just because a business has a physical location, it's going to have better customer service?
